JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is represented before ORG by Ms M. Sykulska - Przybysz , a lawyer practising in PERSON . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) are represented by their Agent , Mr J. Wolasiewicz of ORG .
On DATE the ORG remanded the applicant in custody on suspicion of armed robbery .

On DATE the prosecution filed a bill of indictment with ORG . The applicant was charged with several counts of armed robbery which had been committed in an organised armed criminal group . The first hearing in the case was held on DATE . ORG held CARDINAL hearings and heard CARDINAL witnesses . However , a number of hearings in DATE were cancelled .
On DATE the President of the Criminal Section IV of the ORG assigned a new judge rapporteur . Consequently , the trial had to be restarted .

On DATE the ORG ordered the applicant ’s release under police supervision . On DATE the trial court made a further severance order and split the case into CARDINAL separate cases . It appears that the charges against the applicant were to be examined in CARDINAL separate sets of proceedings .
It appears that the proceedings against the applicant are still pending before the first - instance court .

On DATE the applicant filed with ORG a complaint about a breach of his right to a trial within a reasonable time and asked for compensation . He relied on CARDINAL of the LAW June CARDINAL on complaints about a breach of the right to a trial within a reasonable time ( “ the CARDINAL Act ” ) .

On DATE ORG dismissed his complaint as unfounded , having regard to the criteria set out in section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act , namely the conduct of the court and of the parties , the nature of the case , its factual and legal complexity and what was at stake in the proceedings for the complainant . It held that there had been no unreasonable delays in the proceedings within the meaning of LAW . In respect of the proceedings in the applicant ’s case , ORG found that there had been no delays after the entry into force of DATE Act .

The legal provisions applicable at the material time as well as matters of practice are set out in paragraphs CARDINAL of the decision given by ORG in the case of ORG v. GPE DATE . ) , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ECHR CARDINAL-V
